content: Changed difficulty from easy to medium due to very low success rate (<37%).

@Rafarafa I would strongly suggest to format "can not unambiguously" in **bold** in the statement so that similar complaints (see the latest comments in the forum) will not pop up from time to time :joy:

Added test nº10. This one may affect some solutions. It prevents getting away with a 2 level depth only backtrack that wasn't been tested anywhere else.
As of posting this, it only breaks one python solution that I can see (which is where I saw this inconsistency).

Added test nº9. It shouldn't affect anyone's solution but you never know. 
For the reason behind confer @Math_Genius comment thread just below.

My program is identifying 2 different ways to decipher the final test (and the validator also) and after manual inspection, I believe it's technically correct

SAPIENPURUS, SAPIEN, and PURUS all appear in the word list, so it's ambiguous how to interpret  SAPIENPURUS in the sentence

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle. Statement is well written. Test cases are comprehensive. It's a challenging puzzle, but I agree with everybody else that the harder end of "easy" is still appropriate. Great job!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle, a bit of optimization is required for the last test/validator but shouldn't be too hard for the easy category.  
Statement is clear and test cases are well constructed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle. I like it, maybe a bit hard for an easy one but it's ok. For the future try making this into a hard problem: The original string has length of at most 100.000, there are at most 100.000 string in the array of words and the sum of lengths of words is at most 200.000. This problem is solvable with dynamic programming and hashes. One key observation is that in those words there are at most an order of O(sqrt(SumLength))  different string lengths. The whole puzzle would be pretty hard to solve. For now the problem in this state is nice and unique.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Nice one. More difficult than it looks like at first sight, but rating easy should be appropriate.

Good job, I liked this puzzle, nice puzzle to work on recursion.
I don't have any remarks about the statement or the test cases, looks like everything's covered, I would definitely approve that one.

Input section
* Please format the line numbers in <<bold>>.

Constraints section
* I don't understand the third constraint. Do you mean:
Each word in [[words]] appears the same number of times in [[words]] and in [[original]].
? If so, I would suggest to rewrite it accordingly.

* The last constraint: Please change "it" to "is".

Thanks.

So this is the 3rd version (lol...) of this: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/43212c56cf7dbd6bb25ba9b737151161f0169?comment=104131

New things:
- New tests that should (hopefully) be more clear and cover a wider range.
- Now you should also assess if you can unambiguously decipher the original sentence.
- A performance check at the end. Very easy nonetheless. 

To the random person who keeps replacing my solution with his/her, I've tested it and now you won't pass some tests (Combo, Unsolvable, Performance 2). 

Try to cheese* it again, this is kind of fun :P

* Tbh it was my fault and your solutions actually forced me to rewrite it so thanks for that.
But please, if you happen to read this, post your solution in the comments instead. It's easier to compare and I don't have to pull my saved solution every time.
Thanks, fixed. I included your sentence, it was definitely clearer.

@cedricdd, I'm interested in your recursive approach. How fast are you able to do the big test cases? Just like with Killer Sudoku, I created lists of possible locations for each word and then eliminated candidate locations until every word only had a single possibility. The 140 word Performance test case and validator are both finishing in under 10 ms.

Thanks. It may indeed be a little on the hard side but you are sort of escorted by the tests and there's no gotcha moments (unless we count the "Unsolvable" condition?) so I think it still fits on the easy category.

Now for the harder version, that is currently impossible in codingame, the last test you see here is very close to the I/O limits of a puzzle (1k chars for output and last test is 971 chars), so no more complexity can be added without drastically changing the puzzle.
Oh, I didn't actually realize that each word will be used a single time; that should resolve the ambiguity
Sure thing

I am not sure about this. The solution is long to get, but uses quite simple tools.
Not an easy easy puzzle, but i'm not sure it has the difficulty of a medium.

Ah, I see what you mean, maybe I should have added a small test for that before. Something like (very similar to the unsolvable validator, but solvable):

ABABCECE
ABCE AB CE
-> AB ABCE CE

Edit: while "each word will be used a single time" is not said directly (I think it's ambiguous since words can be repeated...), it's a consequence of:
" Every test has at least one solution "
and 
" Each word in words appears the same number of times in words and in original. " 

But I agree that it could have been stated more clearly.
I ended up adding your test (nº9), I hope I didn't break anyone's code (it really shouldn't since it appears again on the last test)
I don't use that much codingame and did not know that there is a restriction for I/O size. In this case there is no point in modyfing the puzzle!

Hi,

The test/validator with 140 words takes me ~2ms on CG IDE
Same here, ~2ms on CG IDE in Python (basically the same logic as my OCaml solution, which is nothing but a translation of the Python one)
